topics.author: 4f41ee04945b701c41002af7

topics.body:
You know I talk a lot about future tech, but what do you think the world's going to wind up eventually being?


Personally I'm partial towards mega-cities where everyone lives in extremely small areas for the large population.  Like the average skyscrapper will house potentially a million people or so.  The problem with mega-towers is that right now the cost is too high.  It's not that we couldn't do it; rather it's going to be decades until the cost is cheap enough to build.
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53ab9c956368721346580200#post_53ab9c956368721346580200


i feel like its going to be in like those superbuildings programs. large skycrappers build with so much room to house everything from basic to leisure needs.
topics.author: 5154c5237f123bcd580002fc

topics.body:
"@twistedmetalero":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53ab9d4763687213b87f0200#post_53ab9d4763687213b87f0200
That's the safest bet cause people are constantly moving towards the city almost globally.

The reason why we don't have them yet is cost; a million person skyscraper would cost nearly a trillion dollars currently, but with 3d printing for manufacturing and other upcoming technologies that sticker price will drop drastically and become a little bit more realistic eventually someone's going to do it though when the cost is low enough.
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

"@Randomosaur":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53ab96ea636872135cb30000#post_53ab96ea636872135cb30000

topics.body:
I a see a future where the automation of the manufacturing field - and already agriculture - will upturn many traditional jobs and flood the IT field and other degree holding positions creating a massive disparity in the work market and millions of likely unemployed people, or under employed.

In a world where many of the work-horse functions of society of increasing automation the value of the human back and muscle will be lost as unemployment subsidies will become the norm. And the growth of international population will strain the subsidy programs and the economy for the individual will collapse around them as they fall free because the structure of the world is now built without them. Thereby creating massive social unrest.

I see it burning, frankly.
topics.author: 4fe4bf947f123b175b000001

topics.body:
"@AaronMk":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53aba034636872136e0c0300#post_53aba034636872136e0c0300
[bq="AaronMk"]I a see a future where the automation of the manufacturing field - and already agriculture - will upturn many traditional jobs and flood the IT field and other degree holding positions creating a massive disparity in the work market and millions of likely unemployed people, or under employed.

In a world where many of the work-horse functions of society of increasing automation the value of the human back and muscle will be lost as unemployment subsidies will become the norm. And the growth of international population will strain the subsidy programs and the economy for the individual will collapse around them as they fall free because the structure of the world is now built without them. Thereby creating massive social unrest.

I see it burning, frankly.[/bq]
Kind of agree; kind of disagree.  The most likely thing that will happen with that is birth rates will continue to drop offsetting most of this.  In some countries the birth rate per couple is nearing one; give it a couple decades and countries will have to have immigrants to offset the population decline or face economic stagnation.  What I mean by this is that more and more countries will adopt mass immigration to keep population from free falling due to low birth rates or face free falling population like how Japan has a severe problem with population growth right now and refuses immigrants due to social reasons.

To use a analogy the birth rate in the usa the last couple of years has gone from 2.1 to 1.8; what's worse is this continues to slip; eventually it's going to slip to the point where population decline becomes a severe economic problem. . . and honestly I don't care about free falling birth rates cause it's actually going to offset long term loss of jobs due to technology change so call me a prick or whatever, but the birth rate decline is actually good in that it's offsetting potential future economic decline due to changes in technologies.
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600
